en.Slide 1: Let's see how we can guess the closed form solution of the recurrence $T(n) = T(n-1) + 1$
en.Slide 2.1: For a problem of size $n$, we have $1$ unit of work plus the amount of work required for one subproblem of size $n-1$
en.Slide 3.1: For a problem of size $n-1$, we have $1$ unit of work plus the amount of work required for one subproblem of size $n-2$
en.Slide 4.1: For a problem of size $n-2$, we have $1$ unit of work plus the amount of work required for one subproblem of size $n-3$
en.Slide 5.1: For a problem of size $n-3$, we have $1$ unit of work plus the amount of work required for one subproblem of size $n-4$
en.Slide 6.1: This pattern will continue till we reach a subproblem of size $1$
en.Slide 7: Thus, the closed form solution of $T(n) = T(n-1) + 1$ can be modeled by the summation $\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}1$
en.Slide 8: Finally, we have the closed form solution of $T(n) = T(n-1) + 1$ evaluates to $n$
en.Slide 9: Similarily, we can guess the closed form solution of the recurrence $T(n) = T(n-1) + n$
en.Slide 10.1: For a problem of size $n$, we have $n$ units of work plus the amount of work required for one subproblem of size $n-1$
en.Slide 11.1: For a problem of size $n-1$, we have $n-1$ units of work plus the amount of work required for one subproblem of size $n-2$
en.Slide 12.1: For each problem of size $n-2$, we have $n-2$ units of work plus the amount of work required for one subproblem of size $n-3$
en.Slide 13.1: For a problem of size $n-3$, we have $n-3$ units of work plus the amount of work required for one subproblem of size $n-4$
en.Slide 14.1: This pattern will continue till we reach a subproblem of size $1$
en.Slide 15: Thus, the closed form solution of $T(n) = T(n-1) + 1$ can be modeled by the summation $\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}i$
en.Slide 16: Since we already now that $\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^{n}i = \frac{n(n+1)}{2}$, we have the closed form solution of $T(n) = T(n-1) + n$ evaluates to $ \frac{n(n+1)}{2} $
